comment.author: 76204898@N00
comment._content: This is the Brasserie Bougeneaux in the Boulevard de Strasbourg, 10th Arrondissement of Paris: Baedeker: Paris and Environs, 1913: Gare de l'Est (PI. B, 24; p. 217) : Brass. Bougeneaux, 9 Rue de Strasbourg, corner of the boulevard ; No. 11, Rest. Schaeffer, good ; No. 13, Rest. de l'Hot. Français (Barbotte); No. 8, Coeurdoux plain, but good; No. 6, corner of Rue d'Alsace, Bouillon Duval; No. 5, Terminus Est, at the hotel (p. 10). — Drouant, 79 Boul. de Strasbourg, corner of Rue St-Laurent, a large and very popular establishment (oysters). Today's view: maps.google.com/maps?q=9,+bd+de+strasbourg,+paris The Bd de Strasbourg does in fact lead directly to the Gare de l'Est (note correct capitalization). [http://www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/5939636361/]

comment.author: 92284803@N00
comment._content:
The presence of a flag of known colors clearly visible in the image gives us a rare opportunity to reasonably determine what filter was used over the camera's lens. Assuming that the color pattern is correctly oriented towards us, the stripes would be blue-white-red. From the relative shades of these colors on the flag, and based on my limited filter experience, it seems reasonable this photo was taken with a green filter, which is normally reserved for portraits. 

But please correct me if I'm wrong!

comment.author: 76204898@N00
comment._content: Interesting idea! I see two problems: 1. the flag might be hoisted on the wrong (red) side – even though the bearer looks like a gendarme, so he should know what he is doing, and 2. the colors might not be standardized as today, in particular the blue might be lighter. I did a little crude test with digital filters off today's standardized tricolore, and in all cases the blue came out darker than the red.
